column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*Simcoe
column3: ON*Suprun Wealth Management*When asked what frustrates him most about being a financial advisor in Canada
column4: Jamie Suprun is direct and to the point. “Compliance
column5: regulation
column6: and competition from the banks
column7: ” he says. “Clients are completely unaware of the time constraints that regulation and compliance put on us as financial advisors. Most of my mornings are spent dotting i’s and crossing t’s. It’s too bad that a few bad eggs in the system have ruined the batch for the good advisors out there.”

column6: Griffioen identifies time management as his major challenge.

column2: AB*Baylis Wealth Management Group*Now in his seventh year as a financial advisor
column3: Sean Baylis is clear on his targets for 2018
column4: which include “improving our efficiency of operations and money management by converting my book to full discretionary wealth management
column5: achieving vice-president status in the firm
column6: and continuing to grow my business.”

column2: AB*Rusnak Financial*Representing the small town of Bonnyville
column3: Alberta
column4: Ronald Rusnak returns to WPC’s Top 50 Advisors list for the second year in a row with AUM growth of $9 million. Rusnak now manages a total of $115 million across 671 clients.

column2: AB*Milestone Asset Management*Providing financial guidance to independent business owners in Alberta
column3: Steve Booker uses an S-curve formula for planning in order to “develop a framework that weeds out the external noise and allows [clients] to focus on wealth creation through thick and thin.”

column2: ON**Security Financial Services & Investment*The founder of Security Financial Services ; Investment
column3: Leo Belmonte is currently in the process of recruiting new advisory talent. At a time when job losses are a concern
column4: it’s heartening to see that Belmonte’s business is proving to be such a success. Since starting the independent firm in 2005
column5: he has increased his AUM more than fourfold to $116 million. Belmonte does foresee some headwinds
column6: as he expects growth in stocks to plateau pretty soon. This will only increase the need for sound financial advice
column7: however
column8: which Belmonte and his growing team will be happy to provide.

column2: MB*Bonten Wealth Management*One of Wealth Professional Canada’s Women of Influence for 2017
column3: Laurie Bonten is making her third appearance in a row on the Top 50 Advisors list. One of the founders of Wellington- Altus
column4: she now manages $118 million in assets as part of the new Bonten Wealth Management Team. She intends for that number to grow in the year ahead as she adds more talent to her new enterprise. “I would like to expand my client base now that we are at a new firm
column5: ” Bonten says. “I have taken on a junior associate to take over the smaller accounts while I concentrate on bigger assets and client retention/referrals.”

column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*Oakville
column3: ON*The Milley Team*The past year has been a productive one for Oakville-based advisor Greg Milley
column4: and he expects more of the same for 2018. Having added $6 million to his personal book in 2017
column5: he is thinking expansion for The Milley Team. “Our team is now seven people
column6: and I have in place a succession plan for a senior advisor that should add another $20 million to the book
column7: ” Milley says. “One of the seven is himself a new advisor
column8: and we will be increasing client support directly to him. In addition
column9: we are looking to hire a client marketing communications professional in 2018.

column2: ON**Argosy Securities*One of several Top 50 Advisors switching to a fully fee-based based practice
column3: Daniel Noonan is currently in a transition period. Now in his 21st year as an advisor
column4: he is looking to reduce his number of clients
column5: funnelling them to a junior associate to give himself more time to think about long-term strategies for the firm and focus on those clients he can help most. By repositioning himself
column6: Noonan will undoubtedly remain a fixture of the Canadian wealth management industry for many years to come.

column2: ON*Lonsdale Financial Group*Among financial advisors in Canada
column3: fee-based versus commission has been an ongoing debate for years. There are strong arguments for both compensation models
column4: but Brian Lonsdale believes the future of the business lies in a fee-based system. Currently his practice is split 50/50
column5: but he intends to move to a more transparent fee-based model in the years ahead. Lonsdale added $17 million to his book in 2017; with a current AUM of $136 million
column6: his firm is well positioned to grow as the industry evolves.

column2: ON*Rosemary Horwood Wealth*One of the youngest Top 50 Advisors – and a welcome presence in an industry in need of new talent to meet the needs of the millennial generation – Rosemary Horwood believes being relatively new to the business isn’t necessarily a disadvantage. “The proudest moment of my professional career was giving the acceptance speech after winning the Young Gun of the Year Award at the Wealth Professional Awards in 2016
column3: ” she says. “‘A baby shark is still a shark’ was my tagline for the speech
column4: and it gave me the nickname ‘Baby Shark’ amongst my peers.”

column2: AB**HollisWealth*WPC’s Top 50 Advisors list is consistently dominated by those working in Canada’s main population centres
column3: but there’s plenty of great advisory talent outside of the major cities
column4: too. Case in point: John Rathwell
column5: who serves the residents of Red Deer
column6: Alberta
column7: with a practice that has family at the forefront. All three of Rathwell’s adult children work in his office
column8: and he describes the firm as “family helping families.” Rathwell’s team is excelling in that regard
column9: adding $13 million in assets last year to bring its total AUM to $143 million.

column2: ON*AJ Chase Financial Group*In the wealth management industry
column3: less can be more
column4: especially when it comes to clients. Overextending oneself can lead to decreased service
column5: something AJ Chase and his team have taken steps to avoid. “Our primary goal is to continue to comply with CRM2 regulation by being transparent with fees and returns
column6: ” Chase says
column7: “and by reducing our client base to provide a higher level of service – revenue increased by 15.6% by reducing households.”

column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*Saskatoon
column3: SK*PWM Private Wealth Counsel*Alongside fellow Top 50 Advisor Kevin Hegedus
column4: Kevin Haakensen has built PWM Private Wealth Counsel in one of the top advisory firms in the Prairies. That has entailed lots of hard work
column5: but Haakensen says it’s also been a hugely enjoyable journey. “As I reflect back on the last 20 years of my career
column6: I have several emotions
column7: ” he says. “The two largest are a huge sense of satisfaction and pride for the amount of people who have been helped through our practice in the last several decades
column8: and also the number of fantastic employees that I have known and helped reach some of their goals of financial security.”

column2: QC*Sabourin Deraspe Wealth Management*Having an advisor with knowledge of international markets can be a real advantage for investors
column3: and Francis Sabourin has developed a pristine reputation as an advisor with his finger on the pulse of investment opportunities not only in Canada
column4: but worldwide. This ability saw him named Global Advisor of the Year for the second year in a row at the 2017 Wealth Professional Awards. Providing discretionary portfolio management for his clients
column5: Sabourin also boosted his assets by $17 million in 2017
column6: bringing his total AUM to $143 million.

column2: MB*Howe
column3: Harrell & Associates*Next year
column4: Winnipeg-based advisor Sean Harrell will mark his 20th anniversary as a financial advisor
column5: but his long tenure in wealth management hasn’t diluted his passion for the job. “At 41
column6: I still have a few more years to go
column7: ” he says. “That’s OK with me – I don’t wake up dreading going to work. It’s quite the opposite; after a few days off from work
column8: I’m ready to get back to it.”

column2: ON*CIC Financial Group*Marking his 32nd year in the advisory businessin 2018
column3: Brad Jardine returns to the Top 50 Advisors list for the third year in a row. Having built an impressive $148 million book of business at CIC Financial Group
column4: Jardine now takes on select clients by referral only.

column2: ON*Century Group Financial Solutions*Matt Wilhelm certainly likes to keep himself busy – he added 100 new clients over the past year
column3: bringing his total count to 1
column4: 600 – the highest among this year’s Top 50 Advisors by far. Wilhelm also increased his AUM by $25 million in 2017.

column2: BC*CIBC Private Wealth*This year marks Luke Kratz’s fourth consecutive appearance on the Top 50 Advisors list
column3: and it’s an achievement he puts a lot of stock in. “I have been fortunate to have been selected by WPC as a Top 50 Advisor in each of the previous three years
column4: ” he says. “This is an incredible feat for any advisor
column5: but for me
column6: I have been fortunate to continually grow my business – assets
column7: recurring revenue and recurring revenue per client – while shrinking the number of clients that I serve.” Over the past year
column8: Kratz has disengaged unprofitable clients in order to concentrate on those that will drive business in 2018
column9: bringing his current client count to 174.

column2: BC**CIBC Imperial Service*It’s increasingly important for advisors to enhance their value proposition for clients. Although a relative newcomer to the business
column3: Reez Sajan is well aware of that fact
column4: and he believes technology will allow advisors to add value going forward.

column2: ON*Brown Wealth Management Group*The greatest transfer of wealth in Canada’s history will take place over the next two decades
column3: which means forward-thinking advisors like Kate Brown are already adding millennial clients. “Over the past year
column4: I have been asked by five of my clients to connect with their millennial-aged children to help them get started on the right financial path
column5: ” Brown says. Looking to 2018
column6: she has targeted 15% growth in both AUM and net revenue over the coming year.

column2: ON*Caring for Clients*It’s been a year to remember for Rona Birenbaum. Caring for Clients was recognized as the Best Advisory Team at the 2017 Wealth Professional Awards
column3: which Birenbaum considers to be a career highlight. “It was a team award
column4: 17 years in the making
column5: and I’ll never forget that moment
column6: ” she says.

column3: Wolfgang Klein continues to produce the returns his clients expect. For 2018
column4: he forecasts returns of 5%
column5: 7% and 9% for his conservative

column2: QC*Thierry Jabbour Financial Group*Making his second consecutive appearance on the Top 50 Advisors list

column2: ON*The William Vastis Wealth Management Group*A 21-year veteran of the business
column3: William Vastis has managed wealth for many different clients during his career
column4: but one case in particular sticks out in his mind. “I was assisting a family facing tremendous nepotism within stakeholders

column7: but in this case
column8: Vastis’ guidance averted a familial breakdown. “I was able to help mitigate the relationships before it got out of hand and avoid lawsuits and divorces
column9: ” he says. “The business is currently transitioning to the third generation

column2: MB*Christianson Wealth Advisors*A 35-year veteran of the advisory business
column3: David Christianson has been a constant presence on WPC’s Top 50 Advisors list. The reason for that Christianson’s consistency
column4: both in growing his assets under management and in his ability to retain and attract new clients.

column2: AB*Ives Wealth Management*Wealth management is often criticized for being far too maledominated
column3: and the fact that the proportion of female wealth in Canada is set to rise substantially over the next decade has only served to highlight the issue. The industry needs more advisors of the calibre of Paula Ives
column4: who added $32 million to her AUM in 2017 and plans to add another $50 million this year. In addition
column5: Ives participates in WAMCAN
column6: a financial literacy initiative with the City of Edmonton that helps women improve financial literacy and money management.

column2: ON*The Barnsdale & Hussain Wealth Management Group*It’s been a good year for David Barnsdale – 16% AUM growth brought his book of business to $209 million. But rather than resting on his laurels
column3: Barnsdale already has his targets for 2018 firmly in sight: He aims to complete the AFDS course to become a Chartered Financial Divorce Specialist [CFDS]
column4: which should prove useful in the pursuit of his other goal to increase his personal AUM by 20%. Outside of the office
column5: Barnsdale’s main ambition will be taking part in the Ride to Conquer Cancer charity event for the fifth consecutive year.

column2: ON*Alexandra Horwood & Partners*One of Wealth Professional Canada’s 2017 Women of Influence
column3: Alexandra Horwood returns to the Top 50

column2: ON*Wise Riddell Financial Group*A year in which he grew his assets under management by $21 million – an 11% increase on 2016 – couldn’t be considered anything other than a huge success for Mark Winson. The Oakvillebased advisor just celebrated his 30th year in wealth management
column3: but he’s looking ahead with some big plans for the future. Specifically
column4: he intends to move to a discretionary platform and integrate a new partner

column2: MB**Wellington-Altus Private Wealth*With 36 years in the business under his belt
column3: Charlie Spiring is the most experienced of this year’s Top 50 Advisors. He has witnessed wealth management evolve
column4: and with it the role of the financial advisor. Spiring remains hungry for a challenge
column5: however – so much so that he formed his own firm

column9: considering its founder’s history: Spiring previously founded Wellington West Holdings and oversaw that firm’s growth until it was eventually acquired by National Bank Financial in 2011.

column2: BC**CIBC Imperial Service*One of the younger advisors among this year’s Top 50
column3: Joseph Nguyen has nevertheless been able to amass $245 million in AUM during his four years as an advisor. In an industry that can be tough on new entrants

column5: Nguyen received both the CIBC Award of Distinction and CIBC Annual Achievers Award in 2016.

column1: Jamie Townsend*15*Lawton Partners Financial Planning Services*Winnipeg
column2: MB*Lawton Partners*Being a financial advisor can sometimes be a thankless task
column3: especially if the markets aren’t cooperating
column4: but it can also be very rewarding. Just ask Winnipeg-based advisor Jamie Townsend
column5: who relishes working on complex business transitions
column6: which often include creating new shareholder agreements that are backstopped by proper insurance coverage
column7: as well as formulating a business plan to help guide the new owners. “It’s the moment where all the planning comes to fruition
column9: “when we help a business transition from one generation to the next
column10: negotiating the buyout terms and assisting in financing arrangements.”

column2: QC*The Racine-Marcotte Advisory Group*In Nathalie Racine’s view
column3: being a financial advisor is more than just a job. “We love what we do
column4: ” she says. “It’s not a job; it’s a lifestyle.”

column2: ON*Nour Private Wealth Manulife Securities*A fixture on the Top 50 Advisors list since 2014
column3: Elie Nour finds himself among Canada’s elite advisory talent again in 2018. Nour is no stranger to awards – he has ranked among Manulife Securities’ top 1% since 2009 – but he says his two youngest brothers following him into the advisory business has been one of his proudest professional moments. Now in his 11th year as a financial advisor
column4: Nour has his own ideas about what the job should entail. “Today
column5: clients need and expect more than just a money manager
column6: ” he says. “Clients are looking for advisors who can provide guidance in areas such as tax and estate planning.” ]

column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*Vancouver
column3: BC*Luft Financial
column4: HollisWealth
column5: Industrial Alliance Securities*When a business reaches a certain size
column6: it becomes much more difficult to maintain high growth levels. But even though Robert Luft had AUM of close to $250 million in 2016
column7: he still managed to achieve double-digit growth in 2017
column8: bringing his assets under management to just over $294 million. He has his sights set on breaching the $300 million threshold in 2018 and adding 30 new clients to his book. That would bring his client count to 535 – a significant undertaking
column9: but one where Luft believes his team can still deliver a high level of service.

column2: ON**First Avenue Investment Counsel*Returning to the Top 50 Advisors list for a second consecutive year
column3: Kash Pashootan has had an eventful 12 months. His firm
column4: First Avenue Advisory
column5: became First Avenue Investment Counsel
column6: offering high-net-worth clients discretionary portfolio management. Pashootan also increased his assets under management by 28%. Now with $320 million in AUM
column7: Pashootan heads into the new year with every intention to add significantly to that number. He is also a regular commentator on BNN

column2: ON*Richie Group*With an impressive $370 million in AUM
column3: Kyle Richie finds himself among Canada’s top 10 advisors after adding $70 million to his book of business over the past year. That doesn’t mean his ambition has dulled
column4: however – quite the opposite
column5: in fact. “From a business standpoint
column6: we would like to hit $500 million AUM in the next year

column8: we would like to stay ahead of the curve
column9: especially given the recent budget proposal.”

column2: AB*Rouleau Investment Group*The head of Rouleau Investment Group
column3: Lyle Rouleau is making his fifth consecutive appearance on WPC’s Top 50 Advisors list. He increased his AUM by more than $80 million
column4: or 26%
column6: which catapulted him into the top 10 this year. His enviable ranking comes as he celebrates a milestone birthday and plans for another successful year with his advisory team. “I will be turning 50 in January and can see myself still working as an advisor in 10 years
column7: ” Rouleau says. “It may be in a reduced capacity or a reduced number of hours
column8: but we will see where the road takes me.”

column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*Saskatoon
column3: SK*PWM Private Wealth Counsel*Kevin Hegedus returns to the Top 50 list this year
column4: landing once again in the top 10. Hegedus increased his AUM by $66 million over the past year
column5: and he has business-building firmly in mind for 2018. “From a growth perspective
column6: my goal is to bring in $40–$50 million in new assets without a book purchase
column7: ” he says. “This has been our goal for a number of years now and something that we have been able to attain.”

column2: ON*The McClelland Financial Group*In wealth management
column3: consistency is key. It’s a quality Rob McClelland has displayed throughout his career
column4: which is why he has been able to build a book of business approaching $445 million. The Thornhill
column5: Ontariobased advisor has shown similar qualities when it comes to his five appearances on WPC’s Top 50 Advisors list. Last year he was ranked eighth
column6: and he moves up one spot for 2018.

column2: AB*Popowich Karmali Advisory Group*Celebrating a decade in the advisory business this year
column3: Faisal Karmali marks the occasion with his first appearance on Wealth Professional Canada’s Top 50 Advisor list. The fact that he’s making his debut in sixth place – after accumulating assets of $450 million – is even more impressive. Serving 464 clients
column4: Karmali has shifted his business to a fully discretionary model
column5: which has proven popular with the families he provides financial advice to in Calgary. “Clients want to understand the products
column6: ” he says
column7: “and they want to know how and why an investment fits into the big picture for them.”

column2: ON*JMRD Wealth Management Team*London
column3: Ontario-based advisor Reg Jackson returns to the 2018 Top 50 Advisors list with a place in the top five. Jackson stands out from his peers with assets under management of $525 million
column4: boosted in 2017 by growth of $50 million. Although it’s his personal performance that landed him on the list
column5: Jackson is keen to highlight that the success of JMRD Wealth Management is very much a team effort.

column2: Industrial Alliance Securities*St. John’s
column3: NL*ShortFinancial*The sole representative of Newfoundland on the Top 50 Advisors list
column4: Larry Short made it into the top five after boosting his AUM by $90 million in 2017. Any advisor who can increase his book of business by 70% over a 12-month period deserves acclaim
column5: and this veteran is no different. “I started 29 years ago and was called a stockbroker
column6: ” Short says. “Now we complete full financial plans
column7: and I operate as a portfolio manager. Clients have higher expectations
column8: and we have more extensive capabilities than we had years ago to meet their needs.”

column2: AB*SAGE Connected Investing*With 34 years as a financial advisor under his belt
column3: Brad Moore sets the standard for his team at SAGE Connected Investing. Moore had the highest annual growth rate – 85% – of this year’s Top 50 Advisors
column4: which brought his assets under management to $244 million
column5: divided among 274 clients.

column2: MB*Tetrault Wealth Advisory Group*Rising from ninth place last year to second in 2018
column3: Rob Tetrault increased his AUM by more than 50% over the past 12 months. Coming into the business after first practicing law
column4: he has built an enviable reputation during his eight years as a financial advisor. Tetrault brought in 115 new clients in 2017
column5: and he intends for the coming year to be similarly busy. “My business goals are to grow assets under management by another $100 million
column6: to host six quality events
column7: to continue having strong riskadjusted return performance numbers
column8: to grow my social media presence and to continue having a strong 99%+ client retention rate

column2: ABNow in his 14th year as a financial advisor
column3: Chad Larson finds himself at the top of this year’s Top 50 Advisors list. Rising from third place last year
column4: the Calgary-based PM saw his AUM grow 24% over the past 12 months to $776 million
column5: and he intends to stay on that path in the coming year. “We will continue to enhance client engagement with our multi-family office platform
column6: continually enhancing and leading the industry in full-cycle
column7: holistic wealth management and family office services
column8: ” he says. Adding 40 new clients over the past year
column9: Larson takes pride in the fact that he has achieved organic business growth by putting an emphasis on bespoke service. “Too often scale is pursued via product and not process
column10: ” he says. “We will continue to invest in process and people. True scale will be reached with enhanced offerings
column11: using digital tools for client engagement and loyalty.”*MLD Wealth Management Group*While his industry experience puts Larson into veteran territory
column12: he still finds himself at the younger end of the advisor spectrum. Regardless
column13: he has observed how the role has changed over the years. “Clients are more informed
column15: ” he says. “Conversations have changed – they are about the ‘why
column16: ’ not the ‘how.’ The conversations are about family
column17: occupation and recreation – that’s the ‘why’; the ‘how’ is that they entrust us to be stewards of their capital.”
